results.title: Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geography of the Americas”.
This film discusses the cities, industries, agriculture and natural resources of each of the major geographical divisions of Canada. While the film looks at the western region, the central prairies, the Great Lakes region, the Maritime Provinces and the Yukon, it also points out similarities between Canada and the United States.

results.title: Canada on stage
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Tim Wilson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Front-seat view of the annual Dominion Drama Festival in Vancouver’s new Queen Elizabeth Theater. Biggest affair of its kind in the world, the Dominion Drama Festival each year brings together the best of Canadian amateur theatrical talent. “Canada on Stage” shows you scenes from prize-winning performances during the week-long festival as Vancouver plays host to groups from all parts of Canada. Caught by the camera is the taut atmosphere after the final curtain as awards are announced by festival adjudicator Phillip Hope Wallace, British drama critic.

results.title: Canada dances
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
The film relates dancing, both as relaxation and expression, to the traditional and economic environment of the Canadian people. The influence of social conditions on dance forms is demonstrated in a survey which ranges from Indian religious dances, the national and folk dances of pioneers and settlers, the social square dances of rural communities, to the mechanistic individualism of modern jive. Narrated by David Catton.

results.title: Can we please have that the right way round? (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Features John Cleese and James Cossins preparing a slide presentation and looking back at a series of past disasters. It contains the basic rules of slide presentation and operation in a form designed to stop anyone who sees it from ever making the classic mistakes again. Writer: Dennis Nordern.

results.title: Can we live to be 100?
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Donald, Isaac Kleinerman, James Jackson, Peter Poor and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “21st Century”.
At the National Institute of Health in Baltimore, researchers are trying to find answers to the question of extending life. Scientists are studying microscopic creatures called rotifers whose life span has been increased by a drastic change of environment. The possibility that this might be an effective program for human life is the problem posed in the survey. the film also discusses organ transplanting, germ-free isolation for patients, freezing the dead or incurable for possible revival and experiments on the aging process.

results.title: Can we be rich?
results.creator_credit: Cecil Musk and Film Producers Guild
results.brief_description: This film is a discussion by Geoffrey Crowther, editor of “The Economist”, on how post-war British people can raise their standard of living. He states that as a nation we can only consume as much as we can produce, and the basic problem is, therefore, that of increasing production. Using the diagram of a cake to represent the national income, he shows how it is divided, how it might be divided, and how he thinks it could be increased in size. In the course of the discussion, he deals with the relationship of imports to exports; the need for thorough mechanization of industry, including the use of electricity so as to increase production per man hour; full employment, and the necessity of minimum restrictions on the side of both capital and labour.

results.title: Can it hold together?
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
To examine this question, the film brings into focus recent historic events as recorded by the motion picture camera. We see the Commonwealth members in the arena of world affairs frequently taking diverging views on international issues but able, through their very differences, to serve as channels of communication between countries outside the Commonwealth. Edgar McInnis analyses some paradoxical situations that have arisen during the course of the Cold War, in which differing views and opposing loyalties inside the Commonwealth have helped to offset an East-West split. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: Anybody's problem
results.creator_credit: John Fletcher, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: In Britain, the Citizens’ Advice Bureaux give free and expert counsel on problems as different as an eviction threat, the making of a will, a broken marriage and a scooter accident. Shot in Stevenage New Town, the film also illustrates the pattern of life in this new community, one of several designed to ease the population pressure on London.

results.title: Can a parent be human?
results.brief_description: An open-ended film from the Searching Years series which provides role-playing situations concerning communication between parents and children. Compares ways in which parents frighten children with ways in which they make successful contact.
